title: The Body-Mind Connection

content: Sometimes, your own mind can seem to be at work against you.
Take last night.
At 9 p.m., my youngest son called to discuss a difficult personal dilemma. We spent close to an hour talking.

Although I clicked off the phone feeling that we had reached a good solution, once I got into bed, sleep eluded me. Behind my closed eyes, remnants of our conversation circled in my head. Things I might have told him, ways I could support him. Whether I had said too much or too little. Four a.m. found me on my iPhone, doom scrolling, wide awake.

At dawn I rose to walk our dog, my heart beating hard in my chest, eyes circled with lack of sleep.  Back home, I made extra strong coffee, set down the dog’s breakfast, and checked both my texts and my blood sugar.  The first text came from my son.
“Thanks so much,” he wrote. “Problem solved. Slept like a baby.”

content: I stared at the screen, blinking with tiredness.
“Great,” I texted back, then glanced down to see my blood sugar — a morning personal high of 134.
Not a terrible glucose reading, but decidedly not “great.”

As I gathered breakfast things, I mentally ran over what might have caused the high numbers. My dinner had been a textbook balance of carbs and protein: 4 ounces of broiled salmon, one cob of corn, green salad with minimal dressing. Fresh blueberries for dessert. The day’s exercise component had included lifting heavy weights, stationary biking, and some strenuous gardening for my overgrown backyard perennials.
All of which, I thought, should have produced a lower morning reading.

But as I settled at the breakfast table with a cup of black coffee and mini multigrain bagel with farmer cheese, I recalled that nighttime phone call. How my son had been so very upset, how hard I had worked to calm him down. How all of that had been followed by my spinning thoughts, my sleepless night. The answer to the blood sugar mystery suddenly was clear: a hefty helping of stress.

content: Which, much like eating too many carbs or getting too little daily activity, can boost blood sugars.

The mechanics of stress and higher blood glucose aren’t difficult to understand. Stress, anxiety, and depression — all very common in people who are tasked with managing a chronic disease like Type 2 diabetes — and are linked to the fight or flight response. When a body experiences stress, hormones like adrenaline and cortisol surge into the bloodstream, raising blood glucose.

And these problems can not only impact your blood sugar. Mental health stressors can also prompt higher blood pressure, headaches, and insomnia. These are but a few of the physical problems that may be linked to a mental health difficulty. Even worse, stress, anxiety, or depression can overwhelm you in ways that might make it harder to manage your overall diabetes care.
Whew.
Luckily, my extreme stress response was short-lived. A good night’s sleep and some meditation returned me to my normal readings within two morning fasting sugars.

content: Remembering the body-mind connection can make you more clued in about your case of type 2 and what might help. Here are a few ideas if you find that your mind is derailing your diabetes care:

Find a good therapist. This can be tricky. Ask your endocrinologist, primary care doc, or diabetes educator for a recommendation. Some therapists specialize in helping people with chronic disease issues navigate the mind-body conundrum.

Take a stroll. Even a walk around the block can help lower sugars and blood pressure as well as help you calm down and take a breather from whatever is causing your anxiety. Bonus points for heading to a park or wooded path.
Take a relaxing break. Meditation or yoga can provide a space to let you rest. A meditation app can provide a daily break; online yoga sessions let you practice in your own home.
Reach out to a friend. Talking about what’s bothering you with an understanding pal can sometimes help. But remember that your friend is not a trained therapist.
Practice self-care. Choose healthy food. Work on sleep hygiene — a dark room and no phones allowed (!) And work on getting at least 45 minutes of moderate exercise a week — walking counts!

content: If your high sugars persist due to stress, anxiety, or depression, it may be time to talk to your endocrinologist. But by being alert to your own symptoms and feelings, you’ll be better able to fill your doc in on what precisely is going on and to take a more proactive role in your type 2 care.
